EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Noble Energy, Inc. owns and operates the Zif Gas Plant (referred to herein as the Gas Plant or Site) in compliance with OSHA regulation 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119 and EPA Regulation 40 CFR 68.130.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

Noble Energy, Inc. is committed to conducting its business in a manner that protects the environment, health and safety of all employees and the public.

Noble Energy develops and implements incident management plans at each of its operations and also at the corporate level in order to coordinate emergency response at all of its facilities. The plans contain provisions for dealing with potential emergencies and clearly assign authority and duties to ensure timely and effective response.
All personnel at Noble Energy-operated facilities are trained to perform their functions in a manner that protects people, the environment and equipment. We require our contractors to provide comparable training to their employees before they start work at Noble Energy facilities and to submit documentation or verification of adequate training.

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Gas Plant, operated by Noble Energy, Inc., is located in Wayne County, Illinois approximately 8 miles south of Clay City on County Road 2000E.

The Gas Plant receives and processes up to 700 Mcfd of gas from approximately 230 oil wells in a 40-mile radius.  The gas entering the Gas Plant contains Â½ percent Carbon Dioxide (CO2), 12,000 ppm (parts per million) Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S), entrained water, and 5 gallons per thousand of hydrocarbon liquid per 1 thousand cubic feet (Mcf).  All of these must be removed or reduced in concentration in order to meet the specifications for the sales gas.  The hydrocarbon liquid is then processed into the products: Propane, Butane/Gas, and Condensate.

APPLICABILITY

Based on volume estimates and substance concentrations, the following substances exceed the

reporting threshold as defined in 40 CFR 68.130: Propane and the BG Mix (which consists of Butane, Iso-Butane, Pentane, Iso-Pentane, Ethane, and Propane). Based on guidance from EPA's "Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis" (March 2009), Butane was chosen as the representative flammable substance from the BG Mix since it was the predominant regulated flammable component of the mixture. As such, the flammable substances included in this Risk Management Program (RMP) are Propane and Butane. Toxic substances handled at the Gas Plant do not exceed reporting thresholds and are therefore not included in this RMP.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

Since processes at the Gas Plant that are regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) RMP regulation are also subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the incident prevention program.

Employee Participation

Noble Energy, Inc. developed employee working teams, including exempt and non-exempt employees, to review plant operating procedures and participate in the evaluation of process safety hazards associated with the operation of the Gas Plant.  Additionally, periodic written and verbal training sessions with all Gas Plant employees shall be conducted.  During these training sessions, employee feedback will be obtained as to the evaluation and prevention of process safety hazards.  Employee participation shall be tracked using Form PSM-02 Â¿ Â¿Employee Participation FormÂ¿ and the various PSM Review forms developed for each individual process.

Noble Energy, Inc. will develop an in-house incident investigation team comprised of the Gas Plant supervisor and appropriate technical staff.  This team will investigate any incident which results or could possibly have resulted in a catastrophic release of highly hazardous chemicals.  The incident inv

estigation shall consist of witness interviews and site observations in order to obtain facts as to the possible cause of the release or potential release.  The incident investigation team will then analyze these facts and prepare a report outlining possible causes and actions or operating changes which would prevent future incidents.

Process Safety Information

The Site manager maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to ensure safe operation of the Gas PlantÂ¿s processes. These technical documents address chemical properties and associated hazards; limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories; equipment design; and basis process flow configuration information. Specific departments within the Gas Plant are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information. A PSM Plan is in place that addresses employee participation and process safety information.

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs). The Gas Plant is equipped to ensure that the production and refining process is maintained within acceptable limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (i.e., automated shutdown systems).

The plant manager also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction; design pressure and temperature ratings; and electrical ratings of equipment. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.

Process Hazard Analysis

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was used to identify t

he significance of potentially hazardous situations associated with the processes identified in the PSM plan.  A checklist methodology was used by the Process Hazard Analysis Team (PHAT) to evaluate the hazards of each process.  The PHAT included one member with expertise in the operations of the Gas Plant, one employee familiar with each process, and one employee knowledgeable in the checklist methodology.

The PHA will be reviewed and updated or revalidated at least every five (5) years by the PHAT.  The PHAT will use the checklist (Appendix G) during the review process.  Any updates will be incorporated into the PSM Plan.

Each individual PHA will address normal start-up, normal operations, potential problems encountered, emergency shutdown, and emergency operations.

Operating Procedures

In all operations conducted in the Gas Plant, safe-operating practices must be followed.  If any particular operation is not fully understood, it should be thoroughly reviewed by all involved before any activity has begun.  This material is provided as useful reference data to assist the operating staff in further understanding the facility.  Step-by-step operating procedures for various operating modes are presented.  Process flow diagrams (PFDs) have been developed for the Gas Plant.  For the purposes of identification, tag numbers have been assigned to equipment within the Gas Plant.

Training

Training allows employees to learn their jobs properly, brings new ideas into the work-place, reinforces existing ideas and practices, and sets expectations for compliance with the program guidelines.  Training is considered an effective method of communication emphasizing the company's concern for the employees' safety.  Noble Energy, Inc. incorporates safety as an integral part of its training programs, ensuring that employees work productively, safely and efficiently.

Employees are to receive from their supervisors, or other appropriate sources, all training needed in general work

-place safety and in regard to hazards unique to their job assignment.  Training shall be provided:

Upon initial employment at Noble Energy, Inc.

To employees given a new job assignment for which they have not been previously trained whenever new substances, processes, procedures or equipment are introduced that pose a new hazard whenever a new hazard has been introduced in the work-place.  On a periodic basis, for refresher training in general work-place safety, job specific hazards, or hazardous materials, as necessary.

PSM refresher training courses will be required every three (3) years and more often if necessary.  This training will assure that each employee involved in operating a process understands and adheres to the current operating procedures of the process.

Contractors

Contractors, their subcontractors or their employees shall be fully versed in the provisions and requirements of the PSM Plan.  The Contractor shall be fully informed on all local, state and federal laws, regulations, ordinances and decrees that in any manner affects the conduct of the work outlined on this facility.  The Contractor shall be responsible for compliance with any and all local, state and federal rules or regulations regarding the protection of its employees and the general public.  Specifically, the Contractor shall ensure that all employees and subcontractors meet the requirements outlined in the PSM Plan.

All incidents, illnesses and injuries occurring during the conduct of any work at this facility shall be reported as soon as possible, but no later than 24 hours after the incident, to a designated representative of Noble Energy, Inc.

The Contractor shall ensure that all work conducted shall be completed in a manner to prevent the creation or spread of environmental pollution.  For the purpose of this document, environmental pollution is defined as the presence of chemical, physical or biological elements or agents that adversely affect human health or welfare, or

degrade the utility of the environment for aesthetic, recreational or business use purposes.  Any incident that results in the spread of environmental pollution shall be reported as soon as possible, but no later than 24 hours after the incident to a designated representative of Noble Energy, Inc.

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)

Noble Energy will conduct pre-start-up reviews before the start-up of new equipment that has undergone major modifications or prior to the start of major projects (e.g. shutdown/turnarounds). Zif Gas Plant facility management must conduct this review before the commencement of new construction and before the commencement of start-up.

Mechanical Integrity

Monthly visual inspections of all storage vessels, process piping, relief and vent systems, pumps and emergency shutdown systems and alarms will be conducted by facility personnel.  Results of these inspections will be maintained in the on-site facility files.

Based on the results of the visual inspections, specific non-destructive vessel testing will be performed when indications of problems exist.  If the visual inspections do not indicate apparent problems, non-destructive vessel testing will be performed once every five (5) years.

Relief valves will be inspected every six (6) months by Gas Plant personnel.  The local fire marshals also conduct inspections every three (3) years.  In the event that the inspections indicate s problem with a valve, the valve will be immediately replaced.

Safe Work Practices

Noble Energy has developed Safe Work Practices for its personnel.  NobleÂ¿s Safe Work Practice Manual provides guidance and expectations to personnel on procedures that will ensure a sound workplace for each operation with regard to protection of the environment, health and safety.  The Safe Work Practice Manual pertains to all facilities/operations and is periodically reviewed and modified, as necessary, to support continual improvement.

Management of Change

Any change that

occurs to the Noble Energy, Inc. Gas Plant will be managed within NobleÂ¿s MOC Data Management System.  Â¿ChangeÂ¿ is defined to include all modifications to equipment, procedures, raw materials, and processing conditions other than Â¿like for likeÂ¿.

Prior to any change occurring at the Gas Plant, the change shall be analyzed using accepted engineering practices.  The analysis shall review the description and purpose of the change, the technical basis for the change, and impacts of the change to existing systems.  Also, prior to the change, a hazard analysis of the change shall be conducted.  The results of the hazard analysis, including other procedures documented, shall be input into NobleÂ¿s MOC Data Management System.

In the event that the change is to be a temporary change, the management of change procedures shall still be followed.  In addition, the duration of the temporary change shall be included in NobleÂ¿s MOC Data Management System.

Incident Investigation

Any and all incidents, near misses, and incidents must be reported to the Plant Supervisor within 24 hours of the incident for possible investigation.  The purpose of an incident investigation is to find the cause of an incident and implement corrective measures Â¿ it is not intended to assign blame.  A thorough and properly completed incident investigation is necessary to obtain the facts.  The investigation should focus on causes and hazards.  The majority of incidents do not cause injury or illness but result in property or equipment damage, lost time and materials, etc.  These incidents usually indicate an unsafe act, faulty procedure or hidden hazard.  Investigations of these occurrences will be conducted by the Plant Supervisor, members of the EHS team, and any other pertinent personnel.

Employees who have experienced an injury or illness at work must report it to the Plant Supervisor as soon as possible and seek medical assistance.  The Plant Supervisor will take steps in addressing causes

, means, effects and prevention of the hazards leading to the injury or illness.  The Near Miss and Tap Root program is the system used for investigations.

Compliance Audits

To help ensure that the incident prevention program is functioning properly, the Site periodically conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the incident prevention program are being implemented. Compliance audits are conducted at least every three (3) years. Both hourly and staff personnel participate as audit team members. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to gas plant management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The processes at the Site have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. Following is a description of existing safety features applicable to prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances in the facility.

Universal Prevention Activities

The incident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all RMP-covered processes at the Site.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential incidents that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.

Specialized Safety Features

The Site has safety features on many units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release. The following types of safety features are used in the covered processes:

Release Detection

1. Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms

Release Containment/Control

1. Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases
2. Valves to permit isolation of the process
3. Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters
4. Curbing or diking to contain liq

uid releases
5. Redundant equipment and instrumentation
6. Atmospheric relief devices

Release Mitigation

1. Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
2. Trained emergency response personnel
3. Personal protective equipment

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

The Site maintains a written emergency response program that is in place to protect worker and public safety, as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, the Site has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. When necessary, the emergency response program is updated based on modifications made to Gas Plant processes or other Site facilities. The emergency response program changes are administered through the MOC process, which includes informing and/or training affected personnel in the changes.

The overall emergency response program for the Site is coordinated with the Clay City Volunteer Fire Department. The Site has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations. This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition, the Site conducts periodic emergency audits that involve emergency response organizations, and the Site provides annual ref

resher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances at the Site.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Site resolves all findings from PHAs, some of which may result in modifications to the process. At the current time, no modifications are planned for the foreseeable future.
